utterances: The girls who didn't quite make it earned a reputation for being well, rough and salty and raw.
In this new show, comedian Monique takes 13 of the former ""Flavor of Love"" girls and tries to turn them into polished women.
The winner gets $50,000 and the title Charm School Queen.
In the next episode, the girls competed in an Apprentice-like contest to sell perfume at an open-air market in Hollywood.
(Soundbite of TV show, ""Charm School"")
All right, ladies, I can see you have come to do business.
Here we are on Hollywood and Highland, one of the biggest tourist areas in L.A.
You couldn't ask for a better shot.
Here's the final reminder: the winning team will be safe from expulsion tonight.
All right, that was Mikki Taylor, the dean of students.
Off screen, she's the cover editor and beauty director for Essence magazine, and she's also the author of ""Self-Seduction: Your Ultimate Path to Inner and Outer Beauty.
Mikki joins us now from NPR's New York City studios.
How you doing?
Hi there, Farai.
It's great to talk to you.
So you are one of those people who I think - and this is just me, being someone who don't know how to put on eye shadow -you just must roll out of bed completely done.
You - every time I see you, you look beautiful and refreshed and refreshing.
So you're a great person to teach this class of women, but this has got to be a hard sell.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, thank you so much, Farai.
Actually, it has been a very enjoyable work.
I, you know, I have to tell you, I just am delighted to have joined Monique to do this very critical work for these 13 young women.
Yes, but talk to me about the glistening.
Because, you know, it's like that whole thing, it's like women sweat, ladies - or what is it, women sweat…
Ladies perspire.
…ladies perspire, and who glistens?
(Soundbite of laughter)
Somebody glistens.
It's like you've got to be just, kind of, just sweating to be real about these women and what they do.
I mean, they're not exactly ""Charm School"" material.
No, they're not, and yet they are.
They are perfect ""Charm School"" candidates, if you will.
And you know, Farai, I have to laugh.
I heard you, you know, the comment about, you know, the white-gloved ladies in charm school.

And I am a product of charm school, and, you know, in this country for many years, our - you know, the generations before us, they - that was part of our finishing, that we went to charm school to get everything we needed to step forward in life and be empowered.
And so that is exactly what we are trying to do with these women in ""Charm School,"" on the show.
And it's not unrealistic.
The fact that they are somewhat raw, as you say, and rough around the edges, if you will, makes them perfect candidates.
I - you know, to me, I see them like fertile soil that just needs planting.
Let me break it down like this.
You've got - I mean, the ""Flavor of Love"" phenomenon has spun off these different shows.
You had ""Flavor of Love,"" and then, ""I Love New York,"" and now you've got your show that you're working on about ""Charm School"".

But what is it - do you believe - and this is a much bigger question - do you believe that women need charm, a certain feminine charm and a certain type of aspect in order to succeed, or can women just be like men and judged on the ways that men are judged, whether it's athleticism or brains or other functions?
He just comes and goes, and he's got these weird — this weird apparatus and he attacks people, and it's kind of a monster movie in a way.
Is there a similarity between punk rock and science?
Well, he wavered.
In the past, he said, 100 percent, I'm going to meet with the special counsel.
And now he says he's not so sure.
He says that it probably won't even be necessary to meet with the special counsel because there's going to be no evidence of collusion.
And has the White House been cooperating with Robert Mueller in other ways?
Well, they say they have, but it's actually a very obscure process.
The special counsel isn't talking to reporters.
And all we have to base this off of is the White House's say-so.
They say, hey, we've been providing documents, and we've been providing people who the special counsel wants to talk to.
But it's very difficult to say whether or not they've been fully cooperative.
Before we let you go, what else are you going to be looking for?
What other threads are you following as you continue to follow this story?
Well, there are a lot of interesting developments that are coming up next week.
Steve Bannon - you'll remember him - he is going to be testifying before the House Intelligence Commitee.
And Bannon's testimony isn't going to be public.

But you can bet that what he's going to be asked about, I'm sure, is a lot about his comments that were reported in a book that just came out - ""Fire And Fury"" - where he talked about the president's son meeting with Russians in Trump Tower and said that that was treasonous.
Republicans are going to try to undercut his testimony this week.
Democrats are going to try to tease out more from that thread.
That was NPR's Tim Mak.
Tim, thank you.
Thanks for having me.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Lynn Neary in Washington.
Right now, believe it or not, it's award season - though the Hollywood writers' strike made it hard to tell at times.
But now that the strike is over, we can settle in to Oscar weekend, placing bets and making ""Juno""-inspired sunny delight mixers for Oscar parties.
And who better to usher in the countdown to the ceremony Sunday night than the bagger.
David Carr rates the seasonal Carpetbagger blog.
He was the very first to blog for the all gray lady, and he is joining us today from the studios of NPR West.
Good to have you with the program.
Oh, a pleasure to be with you.
And we want to hear form our listeners as well, release you're pent up award energy.
What movies and actors are you hoping to win the gold?
What are you looking forward to - John Stewart?
Our number here in Washington, 800-989-8255.
The e-mail address is talkatnpr.org.
And you can comment on our blog, npr.org/blogofthenation where you will also find a link to the Carpetbagger blog on our blog row.
Well, this has been a very strange award season, has it not?
Yeah, it's weird to finally be out here.
I normally work the story from the East Coast, and I get to L.A.
expecting also, it's a big statement and - for us.
And I have to tell you this year it isn't really happening.
You know, you have - America involved in a shooting where the most dynamic political election, probably in a half century.
And then, even in Los Angeles, you have a writers' strike.
And it doesn't really feel like party time to be honest.
A few cancelled their after party, and peoples attention s turning just now to the Oscars.
Yeah.
And so - that's even kind of reflected, isn't it, in some of the nominees this year?
There's a sort of - people are writing about how there's a kind of dark side to the Oscars this year just in terms of the nominees even.
As somebody who covers these stuff more than I would like to admit…
(Soundbite of laughter)

…there's a significant disconnect between the sort of energy crisis around the Oscars and the movies themselves, which, as you point out, pretty dark bound other than ""Juno,"" which has gotten a lot of uplift to it, and a lot of people went to see.
But you can't argue that the movies aren't that great this year.
These are five exquisite films.
Let's go over the films.
Why do we go over - just gaze?
Not everybody's paying complete attention to the Oscars, but let's…
There is that thought.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Let's say, what are the five nominees for Best Motion Picture of the year?
We have ""No Country for Old Men,"" which is the Coen brothers.
It's a murder mystery, a chase movie.
It's got the scariest villain we've seen in movies in years.
And there's the odds are favored to win, ""There Will Be Blood."" Paul Thomas Anderson's depiction of Daniel Plainview, which is really kind of a representation of early American capitalism.
And it's starring Daniel Day Lewis who'll probably win best actor.
Michael Clayton"" starring George Clooney, about a lawyer who stumbles his way to a new ethical realization.
More of a classic Hollywood film, much loved - ""Juno,"" which, you know, made it past to 100 million bucks, won an (unintelligible).
The people's favorite I think.
Yeah, the people's choice all the way.
They love that Allen Page.
Then ""Atonement,"" which is a classic Oscar movie, period drama, starring James McEvoy and Keira Knightly - lots of great sets, wonderful costumes, and great music.
Now, that's why it's a little surprise when you said ""No Country for Old Men"" is probably going to win because ""Atonement"" does seem like the Oscar movie of this group it seems to me.
And ""No Country for Old Men"" - that's one that I did see - pretty violent and, as you said, a scary guy right at the center of it.
Yeah.
It's - I think USA Today did a story today about the sort of rise of the antihero this year.
Boy, there's plenty of them to go around.
In ""Michael Clayton,"" you have Tilda Swinton playing a corporate executive who's just at the bottom, a very banal form of evil.
There Will Be Blood,"" you have a capitalist who is self-seeking in a way we Americans don't like to think of ourselves.
And in ""No Country,"" this guy is as much kind of El Diablo as he is human.
(Soundbite of laughter)
No, Farai, I don't.
I believe that our creator, you know, created us man and woman for a reason.
And I do think that ""Charm School"" is essential.
I do think that - and I don't tend to think of it as a charm, maybe in the old-world sense of the word.
I tend to think of it as empowered and informed.
And so the lessons that the women are getting on the show ""Charm School,"" those are real life lessons.
They are reality check.

And so whether you're coming to do business, whether you're sitting down at the table and you don't know what fork to pick up, you don't know how to conversate with the person on the left or the right of you, you don't know how to - you're not media-savvy, you don't understand how to excel in relationships and not be played, I mean, your etiquette, your self-confidence, composure, grace, all these - these are tools.
They're necessary.
And so, yes.
I do think it's essential, in a word.
